fields.content: So you have learned the numbers in Japanese which obviously is very useful but one thing to note about Japanese is that objects aren't simply counted with just plain old 一, 二, 三 etc. There are different counters in Japanese suited for different objects. To count these objects in Japanese, we would attach the normal number kanji, and then add it right in front of the counter.

Japanese actually has a LOT of different counters that are suited depending on the object we are talking about.



If I wanted to count, long, cylyndrical objects, I would use what is known as the 本 counter which is read as ほん, the same way it is read for it's meaning, "book." For example, 9 books would be 九本（きゅうほん). There are some exceptions where the readings changed slightly and some rendaku occurs for example 1 book is いっぽん not いちほん. Luckily, these sort of scenarios where the reading slightly changes is a very common pattern among counters that you get used to really quickly.



Although there are many, many Japanese counters, there is one that is by far the most important and it is simply known as the general coutner because uou really can use it for any situation if you really wanted to. Although it may be weird sometimes to use it, if you ever forget or don't know the proper counter for a word, you can always use this. This counter has a completely special set of readings that you will learn in the next lesson but just to give you a quick preview, some examples would be: (一つ, ひとつ), (五つ, いつつ), (十, とお). You can see they have quite special readings right? Also, keep note the last example, 十 is not read as じゅう but as とお in this case and does not have a つ at the end, this is very unique.
So now that we had an overview of Japanese counters, let's go ahead and learn them!
